abstract.p: Owing to the high energy content of hydrogen and the possibility of converting this energy in fuel cell devices into electric power without any pollutant emissions, hydrogen has grown to be one of the most useful sources of energy, especially if it is produced from renewable sources. In recent years, the development of an efficient process for hydrogen production has become an important goal for energy researchers. Numerous studies have evaluated the catalytic reforming of glycerol for hydrogen production both experimentally and thermodynamically. To enhance hydrogen production and make the production process efficient, researchers have investigated different reforming processes under a wide range of operating conditions. Moreover, the main focus of these studies was the development of a high-performance reforming catalyst that can increase the hydrogen yield and decrease carbon formation and processing costs. Several reforming processes can be used to produce hydrogen from glycerol. This article reviews these reforming processes with emphasis on the common catalysts and the operating conditions used in thermodynamic analyses and experimental work. Although most of these studies have been conducted on steam and aqueous-phase reforming processes, more work on other reforming processes, such as autothermal reforming, partial oxidation, supercritical water, and photo-catalytic reforming, has yet to be completed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hydrogen, as the most abundant element in the universe and with an energy yield 2.75 times by mass higher than that of an average hydrocarbon fuel, appears to be the most beneficial future source of energy, especially if it is produced from renewable resources.1,2 Other factors that make hydrogen attractive as an energy source include the pollution caused by the continuous demand for energy and the depletion of fossil-fuel reserves.3 Although it is widely available, only small traces of hydrogen can be found in its free state. Its unavailability in its free form on the earth is the greatest hindrance to the utilisation of hydrogen as fuel, and the need to explore new hydrogen production technologies is therefore essential. Many hydrogen production technologies have already been established, including electrolysis, thermal decomposition, solar energy cycles, production from nuclear power energy, gasification, biological hydrogen production, and reforming.3

Recently, in rich biomass countries, biomass plays an important role as a renewable alternative source of hydrogen. For example, in tropical countries that contain extensive agricultural plantations, such as jatropha oil, palm oil, and sugar cane plantations, and massive agriculture production, the use of bio-fuels (such as glycerol), which is produced during the transesterification process of vegetables into biodiesel fuel, would be an ideal choice. In these countries, for example, the use of such bio-fuel in energy production would be more efficient than water electrolysis. Moreover, bio-fuel has a lesser effect on the global climate due to the consumption of the CO2 produced during the hydrogen production by the further generation of biomass. Technologies used to produce hydrogen from this source are appealing options.4 Glycerol also can be produced by hydrogenolysis from propylene oxide, sorbitol or by fermentation from glucose.5 Many processes have used glycerol as a starting material in the synthesis of a variety of compounds; glycerol has recently become viewed as a desirable bio-renewable fuel for energy generation.6 Table 1 shows the main processes that use glycerol as a raw material. Because 1 mol of glycerol can theoretically produce up to 7 mol of hydrogen gas, its utilisation in hydrogen production would be a potentially economically viable and environmentally friendly option. One possible option for the efficient conversion of glycerol into hydrogen is the steam reforming process.1 Furthermore, glycerol is an oxygenated hydrocarbon with high boiling point and is biodegradable, non-flammable, non-toxic and safe to handle.7

Unlike the case with ethanol, few studies have been performed on the reforming of glycerol to produce hydrogen.8 In the literature, the reforming processes used to produce hydrogen from glycerol include steam reforming,9,10 partial oxidation (gasification),11 aqueous-phase reforming (APR),12 autothermal reforming,11 supercritical-water reforming,13 and photo-reforming processes.14 Reviewing hydrogen production reforming processes that use glycerol as a substrate material, especially photo-reforming, which has not been reviewed before, is the goal of this article. The review includes thermodynamic analyses; experimental conditions, such as temperature, pressure, catalyst loading, and reactant ratios; catalysts; reactions pathways; and catalyst preparation methods.

sec.title: Thermodynamic studies
sec.p: The importance of thermodynamic studies stems from their capability to provide the required information on conditions that are favoured for hydrogen production. Such studies can potentially predict the operating conditions, such as the temperature, pressure and reactant ratios, that prevent carbon formation and avoid undesirable side effects. Coke formation on the catalyst surface deteriorates its activity because of the reduced surface area and reduced heat transfer between the gas and the catalyst and also plugs the void space within the catalyst, which negatively affects the efficiency of the reforming process.4 Furthermore, the undesirable side effects will result increased production of by-products and minimise hydrogen production. In conclusion, to avoid the conditions that promote coke and the formation of side products and to make the hydrogen production process efficient, thermodynamic analysis must be performed as a prior step to the experimental work.

Glycerol reforming for hydrogen production is a new process and is still under investigation. To this point, only a few thermodynamic studies on this process have been reported. The aim of all these studies is to analyse the effects of the operating variables on the production of hydrogen. Adhikari et al.27,28 has thermodynamically studied the reaction conditions on the glycerol reforming process based on the minimisation of the Gibbs free energy (i.e. a stoichiometric thermodynamic analysis approach). They found that the conditions of atmospheric pressure, a temperature greater than 900 K, and a water-to-glycerol molar ratio (WGMR) of 9:1 are the best conditions for hydrogen production. Thermodynamically, under these conditions, the formation of coke is inhibited, and methane production is minimised. They also found that the greatest number of moles of hydrogen was obtained at 960 K and began to decrease at higher temperatures.4

A non-stoichiometric thermodynamic analysis based on the minimisation of the Gibbs free energy was conducted on the adsorption-enhanced steam reforming process of glycerol for hydrogen production by Chen et al.29 In their study, they reported that the use of a CO2-adsorbent material improves the conversion of glycerol to hydrogen, where the moles of hydrogen increased from six to seven compared to the process without CO2 adsorption. The best conditions for hydrogen production, based on their analysis, are a reforming temperature between 800 and 850 K, which is approximately 100 K lower than the process without a CO2 adsorbent, and a WGMR of 9:1, which is similar to that observed by Adhikari et al. With respect to the operating pressure, they found that a higher pressure is favoured for CO2 adsorption, whereas lower pressures give a higher overall hydrogen conversion.

Another study on the thermodynamic analysis of glycerol steam reforming has been performed by Dieuzeide and Amadeo.30 They have used two different models in their study. In the first model, CO was proposed as a primary product, whereas CO2 was the primary product in the second model. They stated that operating at an elevated temperature and at a high water-to-glycerol molar ratio favours hydrogen production. With respect to the effect of pressure, their analysis showed that an increase in the pressure at low temperatures (<900 K) favours methane and coke formation; however, this effect was opposite when the temperature was greater than 900 K. Furthermore, Rossi et al.31 have used a nonlinear programming model based on Gibbs free energy for thermodynamic analysis of the steam reforming of ethanol and glycerol to produce hydrogen. Their evaluation results showed the same optimum conditions as those established by Adhikari et al.27 In agreement with the studies mentioned above, the thermodynamic analysis of glycerol steam reforming by Wang et al.32 showed that the optimum conditions for hydrogen production are temperatures between 925 and 975 K and WGMR of 9-12:1 at atmospheric pressure.

From these results, it can be concluded that the conditions of atmospheric pressure, a temperature greater than 900 K, and WGMR of 9:1 are thermodynamically favourable conditions for hydrogen production by the steam reforming of glycerol.

For the autothermal reforming process, Wang et al.33 analysed the effect of thermodynamic properties on the production of hydrogen from glycerol based on the minimisation of the Gibbs free energy. They studied the effect of temperature, the steam-to-glycerol ratio and the oxygen-to-glycerol ratio on hydrogen production. Their results showed that the optimum conditions for hydrogen production are at 900–1000 K, a steam-to-glycerol ratio of 9–12:1, and an oxygen-to-glycerol ratio of 1:0.0–0.4. Under these conditions, the production of hydrogen reaches its maximum, and the formation of methane and carbon are effectively eliminated.

Kale and Kulkarni34 conducted a thermodynamic analysis on the dry autothermal reforming process of glycerol. They evaluated the effect of temperature, OCGR [feed O2/C (C of glycerol only) ratio] and CGR [feed CO2/glycerol ratio] on the autothermal reforming efficiency. The best conditions for hydrogen production, according to their study, were obtained at 1 bar, 926.31 K, OCGR = 0.3 and CGR = 1.

Thermodynamic analysis of the aqueous reforming process to produce hydrogen from glycerol was also established by Luo et al.35 In this analysis, three different aqueous reforming processes have been studied: autothermal reforming (a combination of aqueous-phase reforming and oxidation), aqueous hydrogen peroxide reforming and water aqueous reforming. Their study showed that the formation of methane, as a side product of the reforming process, has a negative effect on hydrogen formation and dramatically decreases its amount in the gaseous product. In the absence of methane, the water aqueous reforming gives the greatest amount of hydrogen produced, followed by aqueous autothermal reforming and aqueous hydrogen peroxide reforming.

For aqueous autothermal and aqueous hydrogen peroxide reforming, CO formation mainly depends on temperature, whereas H2 and CO2 formation are largely dependent on the O2/glycerol ratio in the first process and on the weight fraction of H2O2 in water in the second process.

An evaluation of the mentioned studies unambiguously indicates that thermodynamics plays a big role in specifying the ideal reaction pathway conditions that can maximise hydrogen production and minimise the undesirable side effects, such as dehydrogenation, dehydration and decomposition; the minimisation of these effects reduces the required energy and the production costs and makes the process more efficient. sec.title: Experimental studies
sec.p: In the reforming processes, hydrogen in its elemental form can be produced pursuant to the breaking of hydrocarbon molecules in the presence of a catalyst. As a result, the reforming processes become a common method for the production of hydrogen in its unbound molecular form from hydrocarbon fuels.36 To minimise the production costs, which represent the main issue in choosing the production method and to increase the glycerol conversion and hydrogen yield, researchers have developed several reforming techniques and several types of catalysts.

sec.title: Catalysts
sec.p:
The purpose of using catalysts in the reforming process is to activate the reaction and, as a result, to produce the maximum possible amount of hydrogen from the reactants. The selectivity of catalysts toward the main product and its resistance to degradation are the most important factors. Improving these factors is essential because they play a significant role in enhancing hydrogen production and reducing the activation energy required to reform hydrocarbons. The selection of the catalyst used in the reforming process depends on the feedstock. Usually, nickel-based catalysts are used in the reforming of glycerol; however, the major problem associated with nickel catalysts is coke formation. Noble metals are also used as main catalysts and as catalyst promoters, but they are expensive.36 The most common catalyst supports in the reforming of hydrocarbons to hydrogen are α-Al2O3, γ-Al2O3, MgO, MgAl2O4, SiO2, ZrO2, CeO2 and TiO2.37 Table 3 summarises the common catalysts used for glycerol reforming. sec.title: Catalyst preparation
sec.p: Because of the importance of catalysts in the reforming process, researchers have made extensive efforts to prepare catalysts that exhibit improved characteristics toward hydrogen production. Different methods of catalyst preparation, such as impregnation,9 precipitation46 and sol-gel synthesis,32 have been performed by researchers. Although the sol-gel method is still under investigation in terms of the synthesis of catalysts for glycerol reforming, impregnation and precipitation are the most commonly used methods. In the impregnation process, the active metal precursor is dissolved in an aqueous or organic solution. The mixture is then added to a catalyst-support solution. After stirring for a certain time, the catalyst is dried and calcined to eliminate the volatile components within the solution, which results in the deposition of the metal on a catalyst surface.56

sec.title: Catalyst characterisation
sec.p: Because of its significance in examining the nature of active, selective and stable catalysts, the characterisation step is required to identify the structural properties of catalysts. Several tools can be used to study the physical and chemical characteristics of catalysts. The most common tools are X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), BET surface area measurements, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR).37,57 Whereas the XRD technique is usually used to identify the crystalline phases inside catalysts, XPS is used to analyse the surface (to a depth of approximately 10 nm) of the catalysts. The Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller (BET) isotherms are used to measure the surface area of catalysts based on the physical adsorption of gases onto a solid surface. The microstructural investigation of certain catalyst particles can be performed using SEM. In addition, a powerful tool for investigating the local physical and chemical structure of catalyst atoms is X-ray adsorption spectroscopy. Moreover, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) is a useful tool used to identify both the organic and inorganic compounds present in the solid, liquid, or gas phase as well as the types of chemical bonds. TGA is used to study solid–gas systems by measuring the loss or gain in weight of the catalyst as a function of the composition of the atmosphere and the temperature. Using this tool, we can specify the reduction temperature of the metal oxide. Finally, the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) technique is used to reduce the metal oxide in catalyst samples. In this process, a reducing agent (usually hydrogen) is required to reduce the metal oxide.

sec.title: Steam reforming
sec.p: Among the existing reforming processes, steam reforming is the most widely used process for hydrogen production in the chemical industry,4,58 especially from methane.59 Approximately 90% of the hydrogen available on the market is produced by the steam reforming of natural gas. Pursuant to the high-energy state that hydrogen possesses, which is higher than that of the hydrocarbons, the steam reforming reaction is endothermic. Energy is needed for this process to break up the C-C and H-C bonds in the hydrocarbon chain.36 The consumption of energy during the process is the major drawback of steam reforming. Because of the endothermic nature of the reaction, steam reforming has been classified as a low start-up process.

The advantages of this process are that it can operate at low pressures and can produce higher concentrations of hydrogen with high fuel conversion compared to other reforming processes. Moreover, the reformers can be sustained at study-state operation for a prolonged period.60 However, high-temperature reforming is highly favourable for the decomposition of glycerol to CH4.1 In addition, significant quantities of CO may be produced and hydrogen may be consumed through the reverse water-gas shift reaction at high temperatures.36

The steam-to-carbon ratio (S/C) is another parameter that should be carefully controlled in the steam reforming process. Sufficient steam will lead to high process conversion and suppress CO formation. Furthermore, insufficient or excessive steam will lead to carbon formation, which causes degradation of the catalyst activity and a decrease in process efficiency because of the vapourisation energy required.36

In steam reforming, glycerol will reform into hydrogen and other products in a vapour catalytic reaction phase that occurs at a high temperature (e.g. 900 K) and at low pressure (e.g. 1 atm) (1)C3H8O3(g)+3H2Og→7H2(g)+3CO2(g) ΔH=128kJ/mol

Many studies have been performed on hydrogen production from hydrocarbons and biomass using the steam reforming process.61–67 Adhikari and co-workers have performed many experiments on this process in an attempt to enhance its efficiency for hydrogen production by determining the most effective reforming reaction conditions.27,38,40–42 In their study of hydrogen production from glycerol over Ni/CeO2, Ni/MgO and Ni/TiO2, they found that Ni/CeO2, which exhibited the highest surface area (67.0 m2/g), is the best-performing catalyst. It gives a maximum hydrogen selectivity of 74.7% compared to Ni/MgO and Ni/TiO2, which give 38.6% and 28.3%, respectively, when the three catalysts are operated under the same experimental conditions of a WGMR of 12:1, a temperature of 600 °C, and a feed flow rate (FFR) of 0.5 mL/min.40 They also performed another experiment on glycerol steam reforming for hydrogen production over nickel catalysts.68 They found that running the process at 650 °C and 1 atm using Ni/MgO brought the hydrogen production rate to its maximum. Four moles of a maximum stoichiometric seven were produced in this process. In addition, in a different study, they examined the effect of nickel and several noble-metal based catalysts supported on alumina and ceria/alumina (Al2O3, Rh/Al2O3, Pt/Al2O3, Pd/Al2O3, Ir/Al2O3, Ru/Al2O3, Ni/Al2O3, Ce/Al2O3, Rh/Ce/Al2O3, Pt/Ce/Al2O3, Pd/Ce/Al2O3, Ir/Ce/Al2O3, Ru/Ce/Al2O3, and Ni/Ce/Al2O3),38 on the hydrogen production by the steam reforming of glycerol. According to their results, the highest value of hydrogen selectivity and glycerol conversion under the specified reaction conditions were obtained with Ni/Al2O3 and Rh/CeO2/Al2O3. By using these catalysts under reaction conditions of 9:1 WGMR, 900 °C, and 0.15 mL/min feed flow rate, 80% and 71% hydrogen selectivity, respectively, were obtained. Moreover, in a comparative study between thermodynamic and experimental analyses of hydrogen production by steam reforming of glycerol, Adhikari et al.27 found that the maximum moles of hydrogen produced thermodynamically per one mole of glycerol is 6, which is one mole less than the stoichiometric limit of 7. However, the experimental results conducted over a Ni/MgO catalyst were far from thermodynamic equilibrium. This study showed the necessity of finding an efficient catalyst for hydrogen production.

Unlike their previous studies, which were mainly focused on finding the best catalysts and conditions for the reforming process, Adhikari et al.42 studied the kinetics and reactor modelling of hydrogen production over Ni/CeO2 catalysts. For this process, they found that the activation energy and the reaction order were 103.4 KJ/mol and 0.233, respectively. Czernik et al.69 performed glycerol steam reforming over a commercial Ni-based catalyst in a fluidised-bed reactor to produce hydrogen. The hydrogen yields for their experiments approached 80% of the theoretically possible yield for stoichiometric conversion. Hirari et al.47 investigated the production of hydrogen by steam reforming of glycerol over a ruthenium catalyst. They stated that the use of Ru/Y2O3 as a reforming catalyst resulted in a complete conversion of glycerol with a hydrogen selectivity of 90% at 600 °C. The steam reforming of glycerol over ceria-supported Ir, Co and Ni catalysts for hydrogen production has been studied by Zhang and co-workers.46 They reported that the Ir/CeO2 catalyst was significantly more active and selective toward hydrogen production than other catalysts used in their study. A complete glycerol conversion with more than 85% hydrogen selectivity was obtained at 400 °C using Ir/CeO2, whereas the total conversion of glycerol was obtained at 425 and 450 °C over Co/CeO2 and Ni/CeO2, respectively.

Slinn et al.70 performed steam reforming of glycerol by-product using Pt/Al2O3 catalysts. They found that the optimum reformer conditions for hydrogen production were a temperature of 880 °C, a flow rate of 0.12 mol glycerol/min per kg catalyst and a S/C ratio of 2.5. Hydrogen production from glycerol over nickel catalysts supported on alumina and modified by Mg, Zr, Ce or La was investigated by Iriondo et al.3 In this study, the authors determined that the use of such promoters enhances the hydrogen selectivity. Over the Ni/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst used in the experiment, the conversion of glycerol remained constant at 100% with a reaction time of more 50 hours. The high surface concentration of the catalyst in the presence of a Mg promoter contributes to an enhancement of the hydrogen selectivity, whereas the presence of Zr in the catalyst increases the capacity to activate steam. Furthermore, the high stability of the nickel phase under the experimental reaction conditions is due to the presence of Ce and La. In another study by Iriondo et al.,43 the performance of monometallic (Ni and Pt) and bimetallic (Pt–Ni) catalysts as well as the effect of a lanthana-modified alumina support on the glycerol steam reforming process have been investigated. The authors found that the addition of lanthana to the alumina support improves the activity of the nickel catalysts and that the best hydrogen selectivity was obtained when the alumina-supported Ni catalysts were modified with an intermediate amount of lanthana. The effect of nickel catalysts supported on commercial α-Al2O3 and α-Al2O3 modified by the addition of ZrO2 and CeO2 on the reforming process efficiency has been investigated by Buffoni et al.9 Their experimental work showed that the use of Ni/CeO2/α-Al2O3 makes the reforming process more stable. This stability is due to the effect of Ce in inhibiting secondary dehydration reactions, which are responsible for catalyst deactivation by the formation of coke on its surface.

Profeti et al.44 performed steam reforming of glycerol over Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts promoted with noble metals. They concluded that the formation of inactive nickel aluminate was prevented by the presence of CeO2 dispersed on alumina. They also reported that the Ni sites remained stable in the reduced state during the reforming reaction when the noble metal was added to the catalyst, which can be observed in a complete conversion of glycerol at 700 °C over NiPd and NiPt catalysts. Cui et al.45 tested the activity of a La1-xCexNiO3 catalyst in the steam reforming of glycerol and compared their results to the thermodynamic reaction equilibrium. Among the investigated La1-xCexNiO3 catalysts, La0.3Ce0.7NiO3 was the most active catalyst. This activity was reflected in the authors observation of a high glycerol conversion that was close to that obtained by thermodynamic equilibrium at a temperature between 500 °C and 700 °C; the formation of carbonaceous deposits were minimised under these conditions in the presence of La0.3Ce0.7NiO3, and the surface area of the catalyst remained stable during operation.

Dou et al.71 used a commercial Ni-based catalyst and a dolomite sorbent for the steam reforming reactions and in situ CO2 removal in their study of hydrogen production by the sorption-enhanced steam reforming of glycerol. They reported that the optimum temperature for glycerol steam reforming with in situ CO2 removal is approximately 500 °C. At this temperature, the CO2 breakthrough time was the longest, and the hydrogen productivity and purity were maximised. Dou and co-workers, in a recent study on hydrogen production by the steam reforming of crude glycerol with and without in situ CO2 sorption, found that the crude glycerol conversion and the hydrogen purity reached 100% and 68%, respectively, at 600 °C. They also reported that the use of in situ CO2 removal during the crude glycerol reforming process resulted in a hydrogen purity greater than 88% in pre-CO2 breakthrough conditions.72 Iulianelli et al.,73 in their current study on hydrogen production for a PEM fuel cell by the steam reforming of glycerol using Ru/Al2O3 as a reforming catalyst, found that the conversion and hydrogen yield were approximately 60% and 28%, respectively, under operating conditions of 400 °C, 5 bar, and H2O/C3H8O3 (molar ratio) = 6. In addition, they reported that coke was formed due to the acidic catalyst support and that, as a result, the glycerol steam reaction was affected.

Chiodo and co-workers74 have reported a study on the catalytic features of supported Rh and Ni catalysts in the steam reforming of glycerol to produce hydrogen. They concluded that the Rh/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits greater activity and stability than the supported Ni catalysts. They also showed that the steam reforming of glycerol is affected by coke formation because of the large presence of olefins in the reaction stream. In the most recent study on hydrogen production from glycerol over a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, Sánchez and co-workers75 evaluated the performance of a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst with a 5.8 wt.% Ni loading in the steam reforming of glycerol under conditions of 1 atm, 16:1 WGMR, and 600 °C–700 °C. At the beginning of the reforming process, the glycerol conversion was 96.8% and 99.4% at 600 °C–700 °C, respectively, and hydrogen selectivity was 99.7% at 650 °C. Over time, the conversion decreased significantly at 600 °C, whereas the hydrogen selectivity did not change with temperature.

All of the previously discussed studies lead to the conclusion that the reforming catalysts play an important role towards a complete conversion of glycerol as well as a higher selectivity of hydrogen produced. Deactivation of these catalysts by coke formation is the main problem that should be considered by researchers. Nickel-based catalysts are the most active and inexpensive catalysts used in glycerol steam reforming. Furthermore, operating conditions, including the temperature, the pressure, and the water/glycerol feed ratio, significantly affect the process efficiency. The conditions of 500 °C–700 °C, 1 bar and 6–9:1 water/glycerol molar ratio appear to be the favoured conditions.

sec.title: Partial oxidation
sec.p: In this process, oxygen combined with a fuel creates incomplete combustion, where only part of the fuel is oxidised by the addition of an insufficient stoichiometric amount of oxygen. Because these reactions are extremely fast and exothermic, a large quantity of heat is released. The heat generated is used to heat the mixture. As a result, no external heat is required to drive the reactions in a partial oxidation process.60 The advantages of partial oxidation over steam reforming include partial oxidation having a short start-up time because of the fast exothermic reaction and the reaction set-up being comparatively compact because it uses the heat generated from the exothermic reaction to vapourise fuel. The primary disadvantage of partial oxidation is that the catalyst temperature is difficult to control because of the heat generated during the process. Moreover, the partial oxidation process is less efficient than steam and auto-thermal reforming because the partial oxidation reaction produces intermediate species that decrease the purity of the output stream. Another factor which negatively affects PO process is the significant formation of CO in the reformate stream.36,60

Hydrogen production from methanol, bio-diesel, and bio-mass using partial oxidation has been studied elsewhere.76–78 Ahmed and Krumpelt79 studied the generation of hydrogen for use in fuel-cell applications from oxygenated hydrocarbons (CnHmOp) by steam, partial oxidation, and autothermal reforming. Although the steam reforming process produced significantly higher concentrations of hydrogen in the products, the partial and autothermal reforming processes are more practical applications and have higher reforming efficiencies.

Valliyappan et al.80 performed steam gasification, which is similar to partial oxidation, of crude and pure glycerol with and without catalysts. They reported that the maximum syngas production of 93 mol% (with a 1.94 H2/CO molar ratio) and 83.3 mol% (with a 1.67 H2/CO molar ratio) was obtained from pure and crude glycerol, respectively. They also found that the presence of Ni/Al2O3 enhanced the total gas production significantly. In addition, the hydrogen concentration in the product stream was higher in crude glycerol, even though the total gas (L/g) was higher in pure glycerol. Glycerol oxidation experiments performed at different temperatures and with various C/O ratios over alumina-supported platinum catalyst have been conducted by Dauenhauer et al.11 Their study concluded that the hydrogen selectivity increased with an increase in the C/O ratio up to a certain level and then started decreasing again. They found that complete glycerol conversion with 65% hydrogen selectivity was obtained at a C/O ratio of 1.2 and at a temperature of 1055 °C. In a recent study performed by Rennard and co-workers81 on the catalytic partial oxidation of glycerol to syngas over noble-metal catalysts, the rhodium catalysts were reported to exhibit equilibrium selectivity towards syngas, whereas the platinum catalysts produced mainly non-equilibrium products. The authors also stated that the addition of water to glycerol enhanced the selectivity towards hydrogen. Furthermore, the maximum hydrogen production was observed at an S/C ratio of 2:3 over a Rh-Ce catalyst.

The advantages of the partial oxidation process are that lower energy is supplied than in steam reforming, where the heat generated by the reaction is used to increase the temperature of reactants; partial oxidation is also a highly efficient process with better practical applications. Nickel-, platinum- and rhodium-based catalysts are most commonly used in this process.

sec.title: Autothermal reforming
sec.p: Autothermal reforming is a combination of partial oxidation and the steam reforming process. In this process, fuel, water, and oxidant are fed together into a reactor. Because the catalyst controls the reaction pathways in autothermal reforming, the selection of an appropriate catalyst is essential to achieve a good conversion and high hydrogen selectivity. The advantage of this process lies in its heat integrity, where the combustion reaction supplies the energy required for the endothermic steam reforming reaction. In addition, the auto-thermal process has a shorter start-up time than steam reforming because the exothermic reaction occurs on the catalyst’s surface. However, more hot spots are created by the heat liberated from the partial oxidation reaction than can be absorbed by steam reforming, which strongly affects the catalyst’s activity. Additionally, this process exhibits a lower process efficiency than steam reforming.60
The overall autothermal reaction is represented in the following equation (2)Substrate(Glycerol)+Air+Steam→ Carbon Oxides+Hydrogen+Nitrogen

Douette et al.82 have studied the possibility of producing hydrogen from glycerol by autothermal reforming. They determined the effects of operating parameters, such as the oxygen-to-carbon ratio, the steam-to-carbon ratio and the temperature, on the efficiency of the process. A hydrogen yield of 65% (4.5 mol out of a possible 7) of the maximum theoretical yield and 90% of that produced thermodynamically has been achieved by the reforming of reagent-grade glycerol, whereas 4.4 mol of the maximum 7 are produced under similar conditions when the substrate was crude glycerol. However, the coke formation and catalyst deactivation during crude glycerol reforming caused the reforming process to be terminated. The production of hydrogen by the autothermal reforming of glycerol over Pd/Ni/Cu/K catalysts supported on alumina under operating conditions of 550 °C–850 °C, S/C = 3.0, and O/C = 0.3 was reported by Swami and Abraham.51 According to their study, the autothermal steam reforming process produced a greater amount of hydrogen than was produced by the conventional steam reforming process. Silva et al.83 has simulated and optimised hydrogen production by the autothermal reforming of glycerol using HYSIS 3.1 software. An air-to-fuel (A/F) ratio of 5.5 and a steam-to-fuel (S/F) ratio of 3.5 were the best conditions for hydrogen production. Under these conditions, a fuel processor efficiency of 83.6% was achieved.

Dauenhauer et al.11 has studied hydrogen production from glycerol by autothermal reforming over platinum- and rhodium-based catalysts supported on alumina foams. They reported that the reforming process exhibited good performance, with a high fuel conversion and a high hydrogen selectivity. This selectivity was near equilibrium when they used rhodium catalysts with the addition of ceria on an alumina washcoat layer. They also found that the addition of steam increased the hydrogen selectivity to 79%.

With regards to the mentioned studies, the autothermal reforming process has a good efficiency in terms of hydrogen production. Compared to the steam reforming process, autothermal reforming can produce a greater amount of hydrogen with lower energy consumed. Coke formation, which causes termination of the reforming process, is the main problem for this type of reforming. Addressing this issue by enhancing catalysts performance and stability is essential to make this process more efficient.

sec.title: Aqueous-phase reforming
sec.p:
Aqueous-phase reforming is a liquid-phase process in which the glycerol and water catalytically react at high pressures (∼30–80 bar) and at relatively lower temperatures compared to the steam reforming process. In this process, oxygenated hydrocarbons can be converted into various products, such as hydrogen (the desired product), carbon dioxide, water, and alkanes.84 Dumesic and co-workers were the first to propose the idea of using aqueous-phase reforming.39,85–89 Using this process, they could reform biomass-derived oxygenated hydrocarbons, such as glycerol, methanol, and sorbitol, into hydrogen, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and alkanes. Ivna et al.90 and Ana Valiente et al.91 have performed aqueous-phase reforming for hydrogen production from ethanol and ethylene glycol, respectively. Table 4 shows the advantages and disadvantages of the APR process in the production of hydrogen.92 The overall reaction for hydrogen production by the aqueous-phase reforming of oxygenated hydrocarbons with C:O = 1:1 is shown in the following equation93 (3)CxH2x+2Ox+xH2O→(2x+1)H2+xCO2 Table 4.
The advantages and disadvantages of the aqueous-phase reforming (APR) process.
Advantages Disadvantages
Because the reactants are in liquid phase, the energy required to vaporise them is eliminated APR requires more time than that needed for steam reforming to perform its reactions
The conditions of the process are favourable for the water-gas Shift reaction, which reduces the amount of CO produced Operation at high pressures and with dilute feed solutions requires additional energy per unit of hydrogen produced
The high-pressure hydrogen produced in the process can be effectively purified and utilised for further purposes Because a noble-metal (Pt) catalyst is used, the cost of hydrogen production using this process is high
The production of hydrogen from hard-to-evaporate polyols at relatively low temperatures can be performed with aqueous-phase reforming in a single-step process, in contrast to steam reforming, which requires multiple steps To date, APR is only suitable for small-scale hydrogen production
The products can further react to form alkanes and water (4)CO2+4H2→CH4+2H2O

Dumesic et al.39 performed glycerol aqueous-phase reforming in a tubular reactor over a Pt/α-Al2O3 catalyst. They reported that the hydrogen selectivity is 51% at 538 K and 56 bar. Luo et al. have investigated the effects of Pt/Al2O3 catalyst loading and the reaction conditions on the aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol for hydrogen generation.94 Their study showed that a catalyst with 0.9 wt% Pt loading performed best in the reforming of glycerol to produce hydrogen. They also concluded that an increase in the reaction temperature and pressure enhanced the reforming process to produce a higher hydrogen yield. Furthermore, Iriondo et al.3 studied the hydrogen production by the aqueous-phase reforming of glycerol over Ni/Al2O3 modified with Mg, Zr, Ce or La. They reported that the addition of Ce, La, and Zr to Al2O3 enhances the initial glycerol conversion, where the conversion increases from 25% over Ni/Al2O3 to 37% over Ni/Al2O3-La. However, in all of the samples studied, the glycerol conversion decreases to less than 3% after 30 h on-stream. Hydrogen production from the catalytic conversion of glycerol by aqueous-phase reforming over several platinum-based catalysts was studied by Lehnert and Claus.95 They found that the hydrogen selectivity increased with increasing platinum particle size from 78% (at 1.6 nm) to 95% (at 3.2 nm), whereas the glycerol conversion did not exceed 20%. Similarly, the use of a mixture of α-, γ- and β-phase alumina as a support material instead of pure α-alumina led to an increase in hydrogen generation from 1.2 × 10−3 to 7.6 × 10−3 mol/min/g cat. In addition, the rate of hydrogen produced from crude glycerol was lower than that from pure glycerol.

However, the glycerol conversion does not exceed 20%. In another study conducted by Wen and co-workers,48 the activities and stabilities of Pt, Ni, Co, and Cu catalysts, as well as the effect of supports used on hydrogen production, were investigated using a fixed-bed flow reactor. They found that the activity of the catalysts increased in the order Co < Ni < Cu < Pt, whereas the activity of the supported Pt catalysts increased in the order Al2O3 < MgO < SiO2 < HUSY < AC (active carbon) < SAPO-11. Moreover, the Pt catalyst was highly stable, whereas Co and Ni strongly deactivated with time on stream. The noteworthy conclusion of their study was the investigation of two zeolite-supported catalysts: HUSY and SAPO-11.

Even though the Pt-based catalyst showed high stability and provided good performance for the hydrogen production reaction in aqueous-phase reforming, this process deserves additional investigation to optimise the reaction conditions and catalyst composition.

sec.title: Supercritical-water reforming
sec.p: The reformation of hydrocarbons or oxygenated hydrocarbons by supercritical-water reforming is a promising method for hydrogen production. In this process, the best reaction medium used for the reforming of these materials is water under its critical conditions of 374 °C and 22.1 MPa. Under these conditions, water, with its own special properties, can serve as a reactant as well as a catalyst and can thereby affect the reaction pathway.96 The purpose of using catalysts in this process is to reduce the activation energy and moderate the reaction conditions. Sascha et al.50 performed supercritical water gasification of glycerol, glucose, and pinewood in a quartz capillary reactor over Ru/TiO2 and under reaction conditions of 450 °C–700 °C and 5–50 MPa. They reported that the conversion and yields were not affected by pressure variation. They also concluded that the process went on to complete conversion of the substrate to the gas phase only with highly diluted feedstock solutions (<2 wt %).

The supercritical-water reforming of glycerol over Ru/Al2O3 catalysts for hydrogen production has been investigated by Byrd and co-workers.13 Glycerol was completely converted to hydrogen, carbon dioxide, methane and a small amount of carbon monoxide. A theoretical yield of seven mol of H2/mol of glycerol was obtained with highly diluted feedstock at 800 °C and 241 bar. The complete conversion at a very low feedstock concentration was also observed by Sascha et al.50 In another study, Luo et al.49 investigated hydrogen production from the liquid reforming of glycerol over a cerium Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst on alumina supports. They found that the bimetallic Ni-Co catalyst exhibited a good ability to break C-C bonds (due to the presence of nickel metal) and an enhanced hydrogen selectivity (due to the presence of cobalt metal). They also found that the addition of cerium to the catalyst improved its activity by preventing the sintering of the active phase. In addition, the optimum catalyst is that with a Ni:Co ratio of 1:3 with 2 wt% cerium added.

In a recent study on the catalytic and non-catalytic supercritical gasification of microalgae and glycerol conducted by Chakinala et al.,97 the authors found that the addition of K2CO3 enhanced the glycerol conversion efficiency and increased the hydrogen yields. This enhancement is due to the promotion of a water-gas shift reaction.

sec.title: Photo-catalytic reforming
sec.p: Photo-reforming of glycerol is a process where hydrogen can be produced under ambient conditions. It is efficient, technologically simple, ecologically benign, and a potentially low-cost process. This method can convert biomass and water, in the presence of a suitable catalyst and solar light, into hydrogen via the photocatalytic splitting of water and the light-induced oxidation of biomass compounds in a single process at room temperature and atmospheric pressure.98 Daskalaki and Kondarides14 have performed hydrogen production by the photo-induced reforming of glycerol under ambient conditions using a Pt/TiO2 photocatalyst and a solar-light-simulating source. Their results showed that the reaction proceeds with the intermediate production of methanol and acetic acid and finally to the complete conversion of glycerol to hydrogen and carbon dioxide. The hydrogen production increased with a substantial increase in temperature from 40 °C to 80 °C, and the reaction is favoured in neutral and basic solutions. Furthermore, the optimum Pt loading for the reforming process is 0.1–0.5 wt%. Bowker et al.52 performed glycerol photocatalytic reforming for hydrogen production over gold and palladium catalysts under ambient conditions and reported that the hydrogen production from glycerol was higher than that obtained from methanol. Using the same process conditions, the performance of a palladium catalyst was four times better than that of a gold catalyst. They also stated that the system did not suffer from poisoning after extensive testing.

Another study on the photocatalytic reforming of ethanol and glycerol aqueous solutions over impregnated and embedded CuOx/TiO2 photocatalysts to produce hydrogen was conducted by Gombac et al.99 They concluded that the embedded catalyst gives a higher hydrogen production rate than the impregnated catalyst. For this process, only a few studies have been reported. Because of its low cost and because it can be conducted at ambient temperatures, this process appears to be a good alternative for hydrogen production.

sec.title: Comparison between reforming processes
sec.p:
As previously mentioned, many reforming processes have been used to produce hydrogen from glycerol on the laboratory scale. Different mechanisms and operating conditions were applied to each process. Moreover, to minimise the production cost, different catalysts and catalysts supports were implemented in these processes. In this context, because the supercritical and photo-catalytic reforming processes are new and have been investigated on a limited basis, the comparative study considered only steam reforming, partial oxidation, autothermal and aqueous-phase reforming. sec.title: Conclusion and final remarks
sec.p: The major challenge in producing hydrogen is how to develop an active, selective, and stable reforming system. Thus, different reforming processes, such as steam reforming, partial oxidation, autothermal, aqueous phase, supercritical water, and photo-catalyst reforming, have been established. In addition, different types of catalysts with different synthesis methods have been used. From the reviewed studies, steam reforming, the most popular method for hydrocarbons reformation, received the highest number of studies compared with the other reforming types. Photo-catalyst reforming seems to be a good alternative for hydrogen production due to its low process cost and capability to be conducted efficiently under ambient conditions. Nickel and noble metal catalysts, prepared by impregnation, are the most common catalysts used for the glycerol reforming process. The problem with nickel catalysts is coke formation, whereas the high cost of noble metals limited their use. Different oxide-supports have been used in glycerol reforming, but alumina is the most common and stable support. Operating conditions of the reforming process, catalyst synthesis techniques, mixed-oxide support, and mixed-metal catalysts are promising subjects for future research, so as to build up an active, selective, stable and low-cost reforming system.
